column4: 01/20/1953: Dwight D. Eisenhower is inaugurated as the thirty-…
column5: Dwight D. Eisenhower is inaugurated as the thirty-fourth President of the United States.

column4: 01/27/1953: Ralph Ellison wins a National Book Award for Invis…
column5: Ralph Ellison wins a National Book Award for Invisible Man.

column4: 03/05/1953: The Soviet Union announces the death of Josef Stal…
column5: The Soviet Union announces the death of Josef Stalin.

column4: 03/17/1953: All price controls officially ended by the Office …
column5: All price controls officially ended by the Office of Price Stabilization.

column4: 04/01/1953: The Department of Health, Education, and Welfare i…
column5: The Department of Health, Education, and Welfare is created by joint congressional action.

column4: 04/16/1953: Eisenhower delivers his “Chance for Peace” speech …
column5: Eisenhower delivers his “Chance for Peace” speech to the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

column4: 05/22/1953: Eisenhower signs the Submerged Lands Act…
column5: Eisenhower signs the Submerged Lands Act.

column4: 06/19/1953: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are executed.…
column5: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are executed.

column4: 07/26/1953: Eisenhower addresses the American public and annou…
column5: Eisenhower addresses the American public and announces an armistice in Korea.

column4: 08/01/1953: Eisenhower proposes broadening the provisions of t…
column5: Eisenhower proposes broadening the provisions of the Social Security Act to cover more than 10 million additional Americans.

column4: 08/07/1953: Eisenhower signs the Refugee Relief Act of 1953, a…
column5: Eisenhower signs the Refugee Relief Act of 1953, admitting 214,000 more immigrants than permitted under existing immigration quotas.

column4: 08/19/1953: Iranians, with the backing of the CIA, overthrow t…
column5: Iranians, with the backing of the CIA, overthrow the government of Prime Minister Mohammed Mossadegh, ensuring Mohammed Reza Shah Pahlavi's hold on power.

column4: 09/10/1953: Secretary of Labor Martin Durkin resigns, in large…
column5: Secretary of Labor Martin Durkin resigns, in large part to protest the failure of the Eisenhower Administration to propose amendments to the Taft-Hartley Act.

column4: 09/30/1953: Eisenhower appoints Earl Warren chief justice of t…
column5: Eisenhower appoints Earl Warren chief justice of the Supreme Court.

column4: 10/08/1953: Eisenhower announces that the Soviet Union has tes…
column5: Eisenhower announces that the Soviet Union has tested a hydrogen bomb.

column4: 12/08/1953: Eisenhower gives his “Atoms for Peace” speech to t…
column5: Eisenhower gives his “Atoms for Peace” speech to the U.N. General Assembly in New York.

column4: 01/11/1954: Eisenhower sends a special message to Congress ask…
column5: Eisenhower sends a special message to Congress asking for changes in the Taft-Hartley labor law.

column4: 03/08/1954: The United States and Japan sign a mutual defense …
column5: The United States and Japan sign a mutual defense agreement that provides for the gradual and partial rearmament of Japan.

column4: 04/23/1954: The Army-McCarthy hearings begin and continue for …
column5: The Army-McCarthy hearings begin and continue for two months.

column4: 05/07/1954: France surrenders its garrison at Dien Bien Phu to…
column5: France surrenders its garrison at Dien Bien Phu to the Vietminh.

column4: 05/13/1954: Eisenhower signs the St. Lawrence Seaway…
column5: Eisenhower signs the St. Lawrence Seaway Bill.

column4: 05/17/1954: The Supreme Court announces a decision i…
column5: The Supreme Court announces a decision in Brown v. Topeka Board of Education, ruling that racial segregation in public schools is unconstitutional.

column4: 06/18/1954: A CIA-sponsored coup in Guatemala overthrows the g…
column5: A CIA-sponsored coup in Guatemala overthrows the government of Jacobo Arbenz Guzman.

column4: 07/11/1954: The first “White Citizens Council” is organized in…
column5: The first “White Citizens Council” is organized in Indianola, Mississippi.

column4: 07/21/1954: The Geneva Accords are signed, establishing a ceas…
column5: The Geneva Accords are signed, establishing a cease-fire and partition of Vietnam. The United States refuses to sign.

column4: 09/08/1954: The United States signs the SE…
column5: The United States signs the SEATO (South East Asian Treaty Organization) Pact.

column4: 11/02/1954: The Democratic Party narrowly regains control of b…
column5: The Democratic Party narrowly regains control of both houses of Congress.

column4: 12/02/1954: The United States signs a mutual defense pact with…
column5: The United States signs a mutual defense pact with Taiwan.

column4: 12/02/1954: The Senate votes to censure Senator Joseph McCarth…
column5: The Senate votes to censure Senator Joseph McCarthy (R-WI).

column4: 01/10/1955: Chinese Communist Air Force raid the nationalist-c…
column5: Chinese Communist Air Force raid the nationalist-controlled Tachen Islands and seize Ichiang Island.

column4: 01/19/1955: The first filming of a presidential press conferen…
column5: The first filming of a presidential press conference.

column4: 01/21/1955: Eisenhower meets with Secretary of State Dulles an…
column5: Eisenhower meets with Secretary of State Dulles and Secretary of Defense Wilson to discuss a resolution that would authorize the U.S. defense of Taiwan and the Pescadores. Congress approves the resolution on January 28.

column4: 03/16/1955: Eisenhower announces that the United States would …
column5: Eisenhower announces that the United States would use atomic weapons in the event of war with Communist China.

column4: 04/11/1955: Roy Wilkins becomes Executive Secretary of the NAA…
column5: Roy Wilkins becomes Executive Secretary of the NAACP, succeeding Walter White.

column4: 05/31/1955: In Brown II, the Supreme Court orders schoo…
column5: In Brown II, the Supreme Court orders schools integrated “with all deliberate speed.”

column4: 07/12/1955: Eisenhower tells congressional leaders that the Ge…
column5: Eisenhower tells congressional leaders that the Geneva Conference will not be another Yalta.

column4: 07/18/1955: The Geneva Conference opens, attended by the heads…
column5: The Geneva Conference opens, attended by the heads of state of Britain, France, the U.S.S.R, and the United States.

column4: 07/21/1955: Eisenhower makes his “open skies” proposal at Gene…
column5: Eisenhower makes his “open skies” proposal at Geneva.

column4: 07/29/1955: Plans for the first artificial satellites, schedul…
column5: Plans for the first artificial satellites, scheduled to be launched in 1957, are announced by the United States.

column4: 08/28/1955: Fourteen-year old Emmett Till is kidnapped and mur…
column5: Fourteen-year old Emmett Till is kidnapped and murdered in Money, Mississippi.

column4: 09/24/1955: Eisenhower suffers a “moderate” heart attack in De…
column5: Eisenhower suffers a “moderate” heart attack in Denver, Colorado.

column4: 10/10/1955: The Supreme Court orders Autherine Lucy admitted t…
column5: The Supreme Court orders Autherine Lucy admitted to the University of Alabama.

column4: 11/15/1955: Adlai Stevenson announces that he will run for Pre…
column5: Adlai Stevenson announces that he will run for President in 1956.

column4: 11/25/1955: The Interstate Commerce Commission bans racial seg…
column5: The Interstate Commerce Commission bans racial segregation on interstate trains and buses.

column4: 12/01/1955: Rosa Parks is arrested in Montgomery, Alabama, for…
column5: Rosa Parks is arrested in Montgomery, Alabama, for refusing to give up her seat on a bus to a white man. During the following week, the Montgomery African American community, led by Reverend Martin Luther King Jr., organizes a boycott of the city's buses that lasts for more than a year.

column4: 12/05/1955: The merger of the American Federation of…
column5: The merger of the American Federation of Labor (AFL) and the Congress of Industrial Organizations (CIO) is ratified.

column4: 12/26/1955: Eisenhower tries to persuade Richard Nixon to take…
column5: Eisenhower tries to persuade Richard Nixon to take a cabinet post and not stand for re-election in 1956 as vice president.

column4: 01/30/1956: African American student Autherine Lucy is admitte…
column5: African American student Autherine Lucy is admitted to the University of Alabama following a court order.

column4: 02/22/1956: Eisenhower releases $1 billion worth of Uranium…
column5: Eisenhower releases $1 billion worth of Uranium-235 for peaceful atomic purposes.

column4: 02/29/1956: Eisenhower announces that he will run for a second…
column5: Eisenhower announces that he will run for a second term as President.

column4: 03/12/1956: Nineteen senators and eighty-one representatives s…
column5: Nineteen senators and eighty-one representatives sign the “Southern Manifesto,” promising to use “all lawful means” to reverse the Brown decisions.

column4: 04/09/1956: Eisenhower again urges Nixon to take a cabinet pos…
column5: Eisenhower again urges Nixon to take a cabinet post.

column4: 04/25/1956: Eisenhower announces that Nixon will be his runnin…
column5: Eisenhower announces that Nixon will be his running mate in 1956.

column4: 05/31/1956: Eisenhower approves U-2 spy flights over the Sovie…
column5: Eisenhower approves U-2 spy flights over the Soviet Union.

column4: 06/04/1956: In Browder v. Gayle, a three-judge district…
column5: In Browder v. Gayle, a three-judge district court rules that bus segregation in Montgomery, Alabama, is unconstitutional.

column4: 06/29/1956: Eisenhower signs the Federal Aid Highway Act, prov…
column5: Eisenhower signs the Federal Aid Highway Act, providing federal funding for the construction of a system of interstate highways for transportation and national defense.

column4: 07/26/1956: Egyptian president Gamal Abdel Nasser nationalizes…
column5: Egyptian president Gamal Abdel Nasser nationalizes the Suez Canal.

column4: 08/01/1956: Eisenhower signs the Social Security Act, permitti…
column5: Eisenhower signs the Social Security Act, permitting women to retire at age sixty-two and disabled workers at age fifty.

column4: 08/01/1956: The recently discovered Salk Polio Vaccine is sold…
column5: The recently discovered Salk Polio Vaccine is sold on the open market.

column4: 08/17/1956: The Democratic National Convention nominates Adlai…
column5: The Democratic National Convention nominates Adlai Stevenson for President.

column4: 08/21/1956: Eisenhower attends the Republican National Convent…
column5: Eisenhower attends the Republican National Convention and accepts nomination as the party's candidate for President.

column4: 09/29/1956: Eisenhower appoints William J. Brennan to the Supr…
column5: Eisenhower appoints William J. Brennan to the Supreme Court.

column4: 10/22/1956: The Hungarian Revolution begin…
column5: The Hungarian Revolution begins.

column4: 10/31/1956: Israel, Britain, and France attack Egypt…
column5: Israel, Britain, and France attack Egypt; Eisenhower condemns the attack.

column4: 11/04/1956: The Soviet Union crushes the Hungarian Revolution …
column5: The Soviet Union crushes the Hungarian Revolution via armed intervention.

column4: 11/05/1956: A cease-fire is established in…
column5: A cease-fire is established in Egypt.

column4: 11/06/1956: Eisenhower defeats Stevenson by nine million votes…
column5: Eisenhower defeats Stevenson by nine million votes to win a second term. Congress remains in the hands of the Democratic Party.

column4: 11/13/1956: Supreme Court holds up Browder v. Gayle…
column5: Supreme Court holds up Browder v. Gayle.

column4: 12/20/1956: The Montgomery Bus Boycott comes to an e…
column5: The Montgomery Bus Boycott comes to an end.

column4: 01/05/1957: Eisenhower proposes the “Eisenhower Doctrine” rega…
column5: Eisenhower proposes the “Eisenhower Doctrine” regarding defense of the Middle East.

column4: 01/06/1957: Elvis Presley makes his third appearance on the Ed…
column5: Elvis Presley makes his third appearance on the Ed Sullivan Show; and concern that his gyrating dance style is too lewd lead network executives to show him only from the waist up.

column4: 01/20/1957: Eisenhower is inaugurated for a second term as Pre…
column5: Eisenhower is inaugurated for a second term as President.

column4: 02/14/1957: The Southern Christian Leadership Confer…
column5: The Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) is organized in New Orleans. Martin Luther King, Jr., is elected president of the organization.

column4: 03/07/1957: Congress sanctions the “Eisenhower Doctr…
column5: Congress sanctions the “Eisenhower Doctrine.”

column4: 05/06/1957: John F. Kennedy wins a Pulitzer Prize for his book…
column5: John F. Kennedy wins a Pulitzer Prize for his book Profiles in Courage.

column4: 05/29/1957: Secretary of the Treasury George Humphre…
column5: Secretary of the Treasury George Humphrey resigns; Eisenhower selects Robert B. Anderson as his replacement.

column4: 07/12/1957: The Surgeon General reports that scientific resear…
column5: The Surgeon General reports that scientific research has established a link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer.

column4: 08/30/1957: Senator Strom Thurmond (D-SC) filibusters against…
column5: Senator Strom Thurmond (D-SC) filibusters against pending civil rights legislation for a record twenty-four hours, twenty-seven minutes.

column4: 09/09/1957: Eisenhower signs the Civil Rights Act of 1957, the…
column5: Eisenhower signs the Civil Rights Act of 1957, the first civil rights bill since Reconstruction.

column4: 09/24/1957: Eisenhower orders federal troops to Little Rock, A…
column5: Eisenhower orders federal troops to Little Rock, Arkansas, to end the school desegregation crisis.

column4: 10/04/1957: The Soviet Union launches Sputnik…
column5: The Soviet Union launches Sputnik.

column4: 11/25/1957: Eisenhower suffers a vascular …
column5: Eisenhower suffers a vascular spasm.

column4: 01/27/1958: Eisenhower asks Congress for federal aid for educa…
column5: Eisenhower asks Congress for federal aid for education.

column4: 04/01/1958: Eisenhower signs legislation he hopes will stimula…
column5: Eisenhower signs legislation he hopes will stimulate housing construction and help combat a developing economic recession.

column4: 04/02/1958: Eisenhower recommends the formation of a civilian …
column5: Eisenhower recommends the formation of a civilian agency to direct space exploration.

column4: 04/27/1958: Vice President Nixon embarks on an eighteen-day to…
column5: Vice President Nixon embarks on an eighteen-day tour of Latin America.

column4: 05/13/1958: Eisenhower orders 1,000 troops from Caribbean base…
column5: Eisenhower orders 1,000 troops from Caribbean bases to rescue Nixon, if necessary, after the Vice President was threatened on his tour of Latin America.

column4: 05/14/1958: Eisenhower doubles the strength of the Sixth Fleet…
column5: Eisenhower doubles the strength of the Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean.

column4: 06/23/1958: Eisenhower meets with African American leaders Mar…
column5: Eisenhower meets with African American leaders Martin Luther King, Roy Wilkins, A. Philip Randolph, and Lester Granger.

column4: 07/07/1958: Eisenhower signs a bill making Alaska the forty-ni…
column5: Eisenhower signs a bill making Alaska the forty-ninth state.

column4: 07/15/1958: Eisenhower orders the U.S. Marines into …
column5: Eisenhower orders the U.S. Marines into Lebanon.

column4: 08/23/1958: The People's Republic of China resumes the shellin…
column5: The People's Republic of China resumes the shelling of Nationalist Chinese islands Quemoy and Matsu.

column4: 09/22/1958: Eisenhower accepts the resignation of Sherman Adam…
column5: Eisenhower accepts the resignation of Sherman Adams, his chief of staff, after Adams is found to have accepted improper gifts from businessmen.

column4: 10/25/1958: Eisenhower orders the withdrawal of the last U.S. …
column5: Eisenhower orders the withdrawal of the last U.S. Marines from Lebanon.

column4: 09/02/1958: Eisenhower signs the National Defense Education Ac…
column5: Eisenhower signs the National Defense Education Act.

column4: 01/01/1959: Fidel Castro's revolutionaries overthrow Cuban dic…
column5: Fidel Castro's revolutionaries overthrow Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista.

column4: 03/18/1959: Eisenhower signs a bill admitting Hawaii as the fi…
column5: Eisenhower signs a bill admitting Hawaii as the fiftieth state.

column4: 04/13/1959: Eisenhower asks Nikita Khrushchev for a partial te…
column5: Eisenhower asks Nikita Khrushchev for a partial test-ban agreement.

column4: 04/15/1959: Secretary of State John Foster Dulles resigns beca…
column5: Secretary of State John Foster Dulles resigns because of illness; he dies on May 24.

column4: 04/18/1959: Eisenhower names Christian Herter secretary of sta…
column5: Eisenhower names Christian Herter secretary of state.

column4: 04/25/1959: Eisenhower, with Queen Elizabeth, dedicates the St…
column5: Eisenhower, with Queen Elizabeth, dedicates the St. Lawrence Seaway.

column4: 07/15/1959: Eisenhower refuses to seek a Taft-Hartley injuncti…
column5: Eisenhower refuses to seek a Taft-Hartley injunction to end the steelworkers strike.

column4: 07/24/1959: Nixon and Khrushchev have their “kitchen debate” i…
column5: Nixon and Khrushchev have their “kitchen debate” in Moscow.

column4: 09/14/1959: Eisenhower signs the Landrum-Griffin Act, legislat…
column5: Eisenhower signs the Landrum-Griffin Act, legislation meant to combat growing corruption in labor organizations.

column4: 09/27/1959: Khrushchev visits the United States and meets with…
column5: Khrushchev visits the United States and meets with Eisenhower at Camp David on September 25 and 26.

column4: 10/06/1959: Eisenhower invokes a Taft-Hartley injunction in th…
column5: Eisenhower invokes a Taft-Hartley injunction in the dockworkers strike.

column4: 10/19/1959: Eisenhower invokes a Taft-Hartley injunction in th…
column5: Eisenhower invokes a Taft-Hartley injunction in the steelworkers strike.

column4: 01/02/1960: Senator John F. Kennedy announces his candidacy fo…
column5: Senator John F. Kennedy announces his candidacy for the Democratic presidential nomination.

column4: 01/04/1960: The Steelworkers strike ends with a sett…
column5: The Steelworkers strike ends with a settlement.

column4: 01/09/1960: Vice President Nixon announces his candidacy for t…
column5: Vice President Nixon announces his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination.

column4: 01/13/1960: Eisenhower declares his support for Nixo…
column5: Eisenhower declares his support for Nixon.

column4: 02/01/1960: Civil rights sit-ins begin in Greensboro, North Ca…
column5: Civil rights sit-ins begin in Greensboro, North Carolina.

column4: 03/17/1960: Eisenhower authorizes the CIA to begin training ex…
column5: Eisenhower authorizes the CIA to begin training exiles to invade Cuba.

column4: 04/17/1960: The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Comm…
column5: The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC), a civil rights group born out of the sit-in demonstrations, organizes in Raleigh, North Carolina.

column4: 05/05/1960: The Soviet Union announces that is has shot down a…
column5: The Soviet Union announces that is has shot down an American U-2 spy plane.

column4: 05/06/1960: Eisenhower signs the Civil Rights Act of…
column5: Eisenhower signs the Civil Rights Act of 1960.

column4: 05/07/1960: Eisenhower acknowledges that the United States has…
column5: Eisenhower acknowledges that the United States has been conducting U-2 spy flights over the Soviet Union. Khrushchev announces that Francis Gary Powers, a downed U-2 pilot, has admitted to spying on the Soviet Union.

column4: 05/16/1960: The Paris Summit between the Soviet Union and the …
column5: The Paris Summit between the Soviet Union and the United States ends when Eisenhower refuses to apologize for the U-2 flights and Khrushchev refuses to meet with the President.

column4: 07/13/1960: Kennedy receives the Democratic presidential nomin…
column5: Kennedy receives the Democratic presidential nomination.

column4: 07/27/1960: Nixon receives the Republican presidential nominat…
column5: Nixon receives the Republican presidential nomination.

column4: 09/07/1960: Eisenhower asks the Soviet Union to stop supportin…
column5: Eisenhower asks the Soviet Union to stop supporting Patrice Lumumba in the Congo.

column4: 09/26/1960: John F. Kennedy and Richard Nixon hold the first t…
column5: John F. Kennedy and Richard Nixon hold the first televised presidential debate.

column4: 11/08/1960: Kennedy defeats Nixon in the presidential election…
column5: Kennedy defeats Nixon in the presidential election.

column4: 01/03/1961: Eisenhower severs diplomatic relations with Cuba. …
column5: Eisenhower severs diplomatic relations with Cuba.

column4: 01/17/1961: Eisenhower's farewell address warns the nation of …
column5: Eisenhower's farewell address warns the nation of the growing power of the American “military industrial complex.”

column4: 01/20/1961: Eisenhower leaves Washington for his Gettysburg fa…
column5: Eisenhower leaves Washington for his Gettysburg farm.
